data.title: Mr Phillip Johnston
data.meta_description: Mr Phillip Johnston is an Orthopaedic Surgeon at Nuffield Health Cambridge Hospital.
data.text:
Phil is a specialist in treatment of conditions of the upper limb, especially of the hand and wrist. He is a strong proponent for “WALANT” surgery where appropriate, which stands for “wide-awake, local anaesthetic, no tourniquet”. This technique avoids the need for, and risks of, regional or general anaesthetic for operations where such a technique does not compromise surgical outcome or safety.

Common surgical procedures include carpal tunnel decompression, trigger finger release, treatments for Dupuytren's contracture, trapeziectomy and other operations for hand and wrist osteoarthritis. He also undertakes treatments for traumatic conditions including fixation of wrist fractures (distal radius and scaphoid) and reconstruction following these injuries (osteotomy for distal radius malunion and bone grafting and fixation for scaphoid non-union) and has developed a regional referral practice in complex wrist and forearm injury. The British Society for Surgery of the Hand (BSSH) collects surgeon-specific outcome data for trapeziectomy and his scores are better than the national average. Similarly, his BSSH outcome scores for Dupuytren's surgery are on par with the national average.

In total over the past 6 years, he has performed or supervised approximately 3500 operative procedures, or just under 600 operations annually. Within this, on average per year, are 95 carpal tunnel decompressions, 12 trapeziectomies; 65 Dupuytren's procedures, 20 trigger digit releases, 11 scaphoid procedures (acute fixation or treatment of non-union) and 35 procedures for distal radius fracture.

Phil maintains his up-to-date knowledge base having acted as faculty for two major international courses: previously the BSSH Instructional Series, which provides a complete curriculum for postgraduate hand & wrist surgery for senior trainees and Consultants, and as Chairman of the AOUK Principles of Fracture Management course, developing trauma skills in aspiring orthopaedic trainees. In addition, he is the Training Committee Chair for Orthopaedics, leading the surgical educators supervising 75 registrars in 15 hospitals across East Anglia, ensuring that the highest clinical standards are maintained by the next generation of orthopaedic surgeons.
